Learning Track 2: Biomarker discovery

Chosen concept: Differential Expression

 

INTRODUCTION

 

Differential expression is the process that compares the expression levels of genes in different conditions. It compares the upregulation (increased expression) and downregulation (decreased expression) of genes <!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>ADDIN EN.CITE
&lt;EndNote&gt;&lt;Cite&gt;&lt;Author&gt;Pan&lt;/Author&gt;&lt;Year&gt;2017&lt;/Year&gt;&lt;RecNum&gt;554&lt;/RecNum&gt;&lt;DisplayText&gt;(Pan
et al., 2017)&lt;/DisplayText&gt;&lt;record&gt;&lt;rec-number&gt;554&lt;/rec-number&gt;&lt;foreign-keys&gt;&lt;key
app=&quot;EN&quot; db-id=&quot;5rfwpsep155re0erwstvtzreafewx9stzwr0&quot;

of differential gene expression profile identifies novel biomarkers for breast
cancer&lt;/title&gt;&lt;secondary-title&gt;Oncotarget&lt;/secondary-title&gt;&lt;/titles&gt;&lt;periodical&gt;&lt;full-title&gt;Oncotarget&lt;/full-title&gt;&lt;/periodical&gt;&lt;pages&gt;114613&lt;/pages&gt;&lt;volume&gt;8&lt;/volume&gt;&lt;number&gt;70&lt;/number&gt;&lt;dates&gt;&lt;year&gt;2017&lt;/year&gt;&lt;/dates&gt;&lt;urls&gt;&lt;/urls&gt;&lt;/record&gt;&lt;/Cite&gt;&lt;/EndNote&gt;<span
style='mso-element:field-separator'></span></span><![endif]-->(Pan et al., 2017)<!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]-->.  In cancer conditions it can be used to compare healthy genes regulation with cancerous genes regulation. Thus, making it a critical concept in cancer biomarker discovery, where identifying genes that are upregulated or downregulated can lead to the discovery of potential biomarkers for diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment <!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span

BODY

 

In studying cancer, differential expression can be used to identify genes involved in causing tumorigenesis. For example, genes that are consistently upregulated in cancer cells may be involved in promoting cell proliferation, enhancing metastasis, or evading apoptosis. Examples of such cancer genes include HER2 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2)  and Jab1/Cops5 in breast cancer <!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>ADDIN EN.CITE
&lt;EndNote&gt;&lt;Cite&gt;&lt;Author&gt;Pan&lt;/Author&gt;&lt;Year&gt;2017&lt;/Year&gt;&lt;RecNum&gt;554&lt;/RecNum&gt;&lt;DisplayText&gt;(Pan
et al., 2017)&lt;/DisplayText&gt;&lt;record&gt;&lt;rec-number&gt;554&lt;/rec-number&gt;&lt;foreign-keys&gt;&lt;key

of differential gene expression profile identifies novel biomarkers for breast
cancer&lt;/title&gt;&lt;secondary-title&gt;Oncotarget&lt;/secondary-title&gt;&lt;/titles&gt;&lt;periodical&gt;&lt;full-title&gt;Oncotarget&lt;/full-title&gt;&lt;/periodical&gt;&lt;pages&gt;114613&lt;/pages&gt;&lt;volume&gt;8&lt;/volume&gt;&lt;number&gt;70&lt;/number&gt;&lt;dates&gt;&lt;year&gt;2017&lt;/year&gt;&lt;/dates&gt;&lt;urls&gt;&lt;/urls&gt;&lt;/record&gt;&lt;/Cite&gt;&lt;/EndNote&gt;<span

style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]-->.  It is often upregulated, which leads to the development of breast tumour growth <!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span

style='mso-element:field-separator'></span></span><![endif]-->(Menard et al., 2000)<!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:
"Arial",sans-serif'><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]-->. The use of differential gene expression has led to the discovery of HER2 as a biomarker for breast cancer, as a result targeted therapies have been developed. Examples of such therapies include Herceptin, tucatinib and Perjeta which targets the HER2 gene by inhibiting its signalling <!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:
"Arial",sans-serif'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>ADDIN EN.CITE
&lt;EndNote&gt;&lt;Cite&gt;&lt;Author&gt;Menard&lt;/Author&gt;&lt;Year&gt;2000&lt;/Year&gt;&lt;RecNum&gt;555&lt;/RecNum&gt;&lt;DisplayText&gt;(Menard

Elda&lt;/author&gt;&lt;author&gt;Campiglio,

of HER2 gene overexpression in breast
carcinoma&lt;/title&gt;&lt;secondary-title&gt;Journal of cellular
physiology&lt;/secondary-title&gt;&lt;/titles&gt;&lt;periodical&gt;&lt;full-title&gt;Journal
of cellular physiology&lt;/full-title&gt;&lt;/periodical&gt;&lt;pages&gt;150-162&lt;/pages&gt;&lt;volume&gt;182&lt;/volume&gt;&lt;number&gt;2&lt;/number&gt;&lt;dates&gt;&lt;year&gt;2000&lt;/year&gt;&lt;/dates&gt;&lt;isbn&gt;0021-9541&lt;/isbn&gt;&lt;urls&gt;&lt;/urls&gt;&lt;/record&gt;&lt;/Cite&gt;&lt;/EndNote&gt;<span
style='mso-element:field-separator'></span></span><![endif]-->(Menard et al., 2000)<!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:
"Arial",sans-serif'><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]-->.

In contrast, genes important to regulate cell growth can be downregulated, thus causing problems for cell growth which may cause cancer. Examples of such genes include tumour suppressors or regulators of normal cellular functions. An example is the TP53 gene, a tumour suppressor, which is downregulated in cancerous cells <!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>ADDIN EN.CITE
&lt;EndNote&gt;&lt;Cite&gt;&lt;Author&gt;Liao&lt;/Author&gt;&lt;Year&gt;2006&lt;/Year&gt;&lt;RecNum&gt;556&lt;/RecNum&gt;&lt;DisplayText&gt;(Liao,
2006)&lt;/DisplayText&gt;&lt;record&gt;&lt;rec-number&gt;556&lt;/rec-number&gt;&lt;foreign-keys&gt;&lt;key
app=&quot;EN&quot; db-id=&quot;5rfwpsep155re0erwstvtzreafewx9stzwr0&quot;
timestamp=&quot;1725313234&quot;&gt;556&lt;/key&gt;&lt;/foreign-keys&gt;&lt;ref-type
name=&quot;Book&quot;&gt;6&lt;/ref-type&gt;&lt;contributors&gt;&lt;authors&gt;&lt;author&gt;Liao,
Yanling&lt;/author&gt;&lt;/authors&gt;&lt;/contributors&gt;&lt;titles&gt;&lt;title&gt;Studies
of autoinhibition and TPR motifs in the assembly of a transcription
pre-initiation complex&lt;/title&gt;&lt;/titles&gt;&lt;dates&gt;&lt;year&gt;2006&lt;/year&gt;&lt;/dates&gt;&lt;publisher&gt;Yeshiva
University&lt;/publisher&gt;&lt;isbn&gt;0542670097&lt;/isbn&gt;&lt;urls&gt;&lt;/urls&gt;&lt;/record&gt;&lt;/Cite&gt;&lt;/EndNote&gt;<span
style='mso-element:field-separator'></span></span><![endif]-->(Liao, 2006)<!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]-->. Differential gene expression analysis has assisted to identify TP53 as a biomarker for cancer prognosis, and the development of tailored treatments such as translationally inhibiting downstream effects of TP53 gene and selectively killing TP53 mutant cancer cells <!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>ADDIN EN.CITE <span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>ADDIN EN.CITE.DATA <![if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <w:data></w:data>
</xml><![endif]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><span
style='mso-element:field-separator'></span></span><![endif]-->(Morris and Chan, 2015)<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <w:data></w:data>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]-->.

The study of differential gene expression has been transformed by RNA sequencing, or RNA-Seq. Gene expression levels throughout the transcriptome may be quantified using RNA-Seq with high accuracy <!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>ADDIN EN.CITE
&lt;EndNote&gt;&lt;Cite&gt;&lt;Author&gt;Wang&lt;/Author&gt;&lt;Year&gt;2019&lt;/Year&gt;&lt;RecNum&gt;557&lt;/RecNum&gt;&lt;DisplayText&gt;(Wang
et al., 2019)&lt;/DisplayText&gt;&lt;record&gt;&lt;rec-number&gt;557&lt;/rec-number&gt;&lt;foreign-keys&gt;&lt;key
app=&quot;EN&quot; db-id=&quot;5rfwpsep155re0erwstvtzreafewx9stzwr0&quot;
timestamp=&quot;1725313298&quot;&gt;557&lt;/key&gt;&lt;/foreign-keys&gt;&lt;ref-type
name=&quot;Journal Article&quot;&gt;17&lt;/ref-type&gt;&lt;contributors&gt;&lt;authors&gt;&lt;author&gt;Wang,
Jinglu&lt;/author&gt;&lt;author&gt;Dean, Dylan
C&lt;/author&gt;&lt;author&gt;Hornicek, Francis
J&lt;/author&gt;&lt;author&gt;Shi, Huirong&lt;/author&gt;&lt;author&gt;Duan,
Zhenfeng&lt;/author&gt;&lt;/authors&gt;&lt;/contributors&gt;&lt;titles&gt;&lt;title&gt;RNA
sequencing (RNA-Seq) and its application in ovarian
cancer&lt;/title&gt;&lt;secondary-title&gt;Gynecologic
oncology&lt;/secondary-title&gt;&lt;/titles&gt;&lt;periodical&gt;&lt;full-title&gt;Gynecologic
oncology&lt;/full-title&gt;&lt;/periodical&gt;&lt;pages&gt;194-201&lt;/pages&gt;&lt;volume&gt;152&lt;/volume&gt;&lt;number&gt;1&lt;/number&gt;&lt;dates&gt;&lt;year&gt;2019&lt;/year&gt;&lt;/dates&gt;&lt;isbn&gt;0090-8258&lt;/isbn&gt;&lt;urls&gt;&lt;/urls&gt;&lt;/record&gt;&lt;/Cite&gt;&lt;/EndNote&gt;<span
style='mso-element:field-separator'></span></span><![endif]-->(Wang et al., 2019)<!--[if supportFields]><span style='font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]-->.  RNA-Seq has made it easier to identify new cancer biomarkers by revealing genes that express themselves differently in malignant tissues than in healthy ones.

CONCLUSION

In conclusion, differential expression process plays an important role in identifying biomarkers for cancer and is vital to comprehending the molecular causes of cancer. Finding the genes that are up and downregulated offers important new insights into the biology of cancer and creates new opportunities for targeted and customised treatments.
